articles.headline: Parcel for Sale: Plenty of Space. Very Quiet. Light? Well ...
articles.snippet: The Roswell, N.M., site had been the home of an Atlas-F missile, 100 times more powerful than the atomic bomb dropped on Nagasaki. The silo is a fixer-upper, to put it mildly.
articles.abstract: The Roswell, N.M., site had been the home of an Atlas-F missile, 100 times more powerful than the atomic bomb dropped on Nagasaki. The silo is a fixer-upper, to put it mildly.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSWELL, N.M. — Past the city limits, where the main street with the U.F.O. museum and the McDonald’s in the shape of a flying saucer gives way to a lonely highway coursing through an ocean of scrubby terrain, the green door pops up like a periscope.

articles.headline: Devil May Be in the Details on European Central Bank Bond-Buying
articles.snippet: A widely expected stimulus program will be a test of whether the institution and its president can walk a fine political line and show their resolve.
articles.abstract: A widely expected stimulus program will be a test of whether the institution and its president can walk a fine political line and show their resolve.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A court opinion issued on Wednesday makes it all but certain that the European Central Bank will announce a major round of economic stimulus next week, after months of contentious internal debate.

articles.headline: House Measure Defies Obama on Immigrants
articles.snippet: Some Republican members deserted their party to vote against a bill denying safeguards for undocumented immigrants, including the young known as Dreamers.
articles.abstract: Some Republican members deserted their party to vote against a bill denying safeguards for undocumented immigrants, including the young known as Dreamers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Wednesday to gut major provisions of President Obama’s immigration policy, approving legislation that would revoke legal protections for millions of unauthorized immigrants, including children, and put them at risk of deportation.

articles.headline: Mutual Fund Billionaire Accused of Fraud in Suit
articles.snippet: A suit contends that Charles B. Johnson helped conceal $150 million in Franklin Resources shares and dividends that were intended to go to the heir of an early investor.
articles.abstract: A suit contends that Charles B. Johnson helped conceal $150 million in Franklin Resources shares and dividends that were intended to go to the heir of an early investor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charles B. Johnson has been lauded for numerous accomplishments.

articles.headline: Flocking to Buy Charlie Hebdo, Citizens Signal Their Support of Free Speech
articles.snippet: The sentiment that drove the sales probably had less to do with those messages and more to do with the impulse to preserve a world in which the speech of the many cannot be held hostage by a few.
articles.abstract: The sentiment that drove the sales probably had less to do with those messages and more to do with the impulse to preserve a world in which the speech of the many cannot be held hostage by a few.
articles.lead_paragraph: For people who are supporters of not just free speech but newspapers, too, the images of Parisians queued up at dawn Wednesday to get their hands on a printed artifact was heartening. The French distributors of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo said the latest issue’s initial printing of three million copies had been increased to perhaps five million, and there were reports that the now-precious editions were being auctioned on eBay for hundreds of dollars.

articles.headline: Crisis in France Is Seen as Sign of Chronic Ills
articles.snippet: After the Paris attacks, appeals for unity have hardly penetrated the sense of isolation, even siege, felt in disaffected suburbs like Vaulx-en-Velin.
articles.abstract: After the Paris attacks, appeals for unity have hardly penetrated the sense of isolation, even siege, felt in disaffected suburbs like Vaulx-en-Velin.
articles.lead_paragraph: VAULX-EN-VELIN, France — France may have just hosted its biggest outpouring of solidarity since the end of World War II in response to the terrorist attacks last week in and around Paris that left 17 dead at the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo and a kosher supermarket.
articles.byline: By Adam B. Ellick and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Seeking Luxury Deals as Euro Falls
articles.snippet: It turns out that retail pricing, especially for luxury brands with fat profit margins, is far more complicated than just looking up exchange rates.
articles.abstract: It turns out that retail pricing, especially for luxury brands with fat profit margins, is far more complicated than just looking up exchange rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: The strong dollar and threat of deflation may be wreaking havoc on European economies, but as an American consumer it has made me feel flush.

articles.headline: In India, a Banker in Defense Mode
articles.snippet: Raghuram G. Rajan, the governor of the Reserve Bank of India, has become the subject of a political struggle as he reduces a benchmark rate.
articles.abstract: Raghuram G. Rajan, the governor of the Reserve Bank of India, has become the subject of a political struggle as he reduces a benchmark rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — Few central bankers in emerging markets have been as internationally lionized as Raghuram G. Rajan of India.

articles.headline: Swiss Franc Soars After Central Bank Drops Cap
articles.snippet: The Swiss central bank increased the amount it charges depositors to hold their cash, to little avail.
articles.abstract: The Swiss central bank increased the amount it charges depositors to hold their cash, to little avail.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Switzerland stunned the markets on Thursday by abandoning a crucial part of its effort to hold down the value of its currency, concluding that the strategy was too risky and too costly given the enormous forces pushing in the other direction.
articles.byline: By David Jolly and Neil Irwin

articles.headline: French Rein In Speech Backing Acts of Terror
articles.snippet: Recent court cases in Paris have raised accusations of a double standard on free speech with some pointing to a divide between cartoonists and statements made by Muslim supporters of the gunmen.
articles.abstract: Recent court cases in Paris have raised accusations of a double standard on free speech with some pointing to a divide between cartoonists and statements made by Muslim supporters of the gunmen.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French authorities are moving aggressively to rein in speech supporting terrorism, employing a new law to mete out tough prison sentences in a crackdown that is stoking a free-speech debate after last week’s attacks in Paris.
articles.byline: By Doreen Carvajal and Alan Cowell

articles.headline: Target’s Red Ink Runs Out in Canada
articles.snippet: The company, which has made major management changes in the last year, is closing more than 100 Canadian stores less than two years after they opened.
articles.abstract: The company, which has made major management changes in the last year, is closing more than 100 Canadian stores less than two years after they opened.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Less than two years after opening in Canada, Target conceded defeat on Thursday and said it would shutter its 133 stores, bringing an infamously ill-managed northward foray by the American retail giant to an abrupt end.
articles.byline: By Ian Austen and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: 2016 Hopefuls Skirt Leaders of the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: A kind of political free agency, surfacing before the new Senate has passed a single bill, poses an early test for the party as it looks to expand its power and prove it can govern.
articles.abstract: A kind of political free agency, surfacing before the new Senate has passed a single bill, poses an early test for the party as it looks to expand its power and prove it can govern.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican majority in Congress is barely a week old. Until just a few days ago, the new sign outside Senator Mitch McConnell’s office, freshly stenciled with the words “majority leader,” was not even screwed in properly. But an important group of Republicans has already decided that it is ready to move on.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Ashley Parker
